educational_objective: Diagnose idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on chest radiography.
question_text: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for a 13-month history of progressive dyspnea and dry cough. He stopped smoking cigarettes five years ago. Clubbing is present.Chest radiograph is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: This patient's frontal radiograph suggests the diagnosis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (Option D). Chest radiographs in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis may demonstrate bibasilar-predominant septal line thickening with reticular changes (as on this radiograph) and volume loss; changes indicative of bronchiectasis may also be present when the disease is more severe. The best diagnostic test is high-resolution CT, which may show bilateral-, peripheral-, and basal-predominant septal line thickening with honeycomb changes. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis typically presents in patients between 50 and 70 years of age who have a greater than 6-month duration of a dry cough and dyspnea on exertion. Lung examination is notable for "Velcro" inspiratory crackles that are predominant at the bases. Clubbing is present in up to 50% of patients.
